text: That's an excellent question. And it's, you know, it's one I've thought about, and I've used kind of as an illustrative tool when I, you know, talk to certain folks and say, look, this, you know, this is kind of a set it and forget it. If I had to, you know, put everything into one thing for the next hundred years, this would be it. And, you know, in many ways, I kind of, I'm going to, you know, copy what Ray Dalio said in one of his early research reports about the idea of, you know, his risk parity. Now setting aside leverage for a second, there's obvious issues with that, but, you know, it's difficult really to improve upon, you know, a multi-asset class approach. And I would even say ETFs are fine. You know, if it's long enough horizon, you can, I'd be less concerned about the, you know, kind of the wrapper risks, but it would be, you know, multi-asset class. I would have, you know, some kind of, I wouldn't try and get overly cute with the allocation among asset classes. I would, you know, just probably do it on a very simple risk weighted basis, maybe have a momentum filter. Cause the, again, as we all know, and as you've heard about the, you know, the math of just simply avoiding large losses, you know, really does compound over time. And if it's truly set and forget it, you'd want some kind of systematic risk off lever embedded in there, you know, and I don't, I don't know that it would be much more complex than that. So, you know, you can kind of think of it as a risk parity approach, you know, unlevered across, you know, any asset class I could reasonably get access to with, you know, a momentum filter and to go to cash, let's say, and, and, and, you know, true, you know, prolonged risk off environments, you know, 08, early seventies, you know, 2000. Types in areas. I don't, I don't know that I would get overly clever. And then of course, there's the obligatory 50 basis point allocation to crypto, but that's a whole nother thing.
